title: How to Pickle

methods.name:
Kosher Dill Pickles [1]
	X
		Research source

steps.headline: Wash the cucumbers.
Combine salt and boiling water in a large bowl or crock.
steps.description: Stir to dissolve the salt. Kosher salt is a very coarse grain salt which does not contain iodine or any anti-caking additives. Do not substitute table salt. Table salt is fine-grained and usually contains iodine and an anti-caking additive. The additives in table salt may leave a bitter taste, darken the color, and cause the brine to become cloudy. You can pickle in food grade plastic, stainless steel and glass. Containers made of aluminum or copper should not be used for pickling

steps.headline: Once the salt is dissolved, add a handful of ice cubes to cool the mixture.
Cut the cucumbers in half lengthwise.
Add the cucumbers, garlic, dill and enough cold water to submerge.
Using a plate slightly smaller than your container, place the plate and a small weight on top of the cucumber mixture.
steps.description: This will keep the cucumbers under water. Use a clean rock, or anything heavy enough to keep the cucumbers under water. Keep the mixture at room temperature.

steps.headline: After 10 hours, sample the pickles.
steps.description: It will take anywhere from 24 - 48 hours for the pickling process to be complete.

steps.headline: When the pickles are suitable for your taste, refrigerate them in the brine.
steps.description:
The pickles will continue to ferment, but more slowly in the refrigerator
The pickles will keep for up to a week in the refrigerator

steps.headline: Wash the cucumber and summer squash.
Peel cucumbers and summer squash.
steps.description: Cut into slices approximately ¼ inch in diameter. If you prefer you may use thinner or thicker slices. The cucumber and summer squash should be about the same thickness.

steps.headline: Place cucumbers, summer squash and sweet onions in a bowl.
steps.description: You can pickle in food grade plastic, stainless steel or glass. Aluminum and copper are not suitable for pickling.

steps.headline: Combine vinegar, sugar, salt, celery seed and mustard seed in a small saucepan.
Cook and stir just until sugar is dissolved.
Pour mixture over cucumbers.
Cover tightly and refrigerate for at least 24 hours.

methods.name:
Quick Pickled Vegetables [3]
	X
		Research source

steps.headline: Wash the vegetables.
Slice the vegetables as thinly as possible.
steps.description: Vegetables can be peeled or left unpeeled. A mandolin is excellent for this. Be sure to use the guard and be careful to avoid slicing your fingers if using a mandolin.

steps.headline: Place the vegetables in a colander and salt them.
Toss the sliced vegetables with the salt, working the salt into the vegetables with your hands for a minute.
Let the vegetables sit in the colander for 15 - 30 minute, tossing and squeezing every few minutes.
steps.description:
Continue until  little to no liquid can be squeezed out of the vegetables
Cucumbers take less time; eggplant takes more time.

steps.headline: Rinse the vegetables well in cold water.
Place in a bowl.
steps.description: You can pickle in food grade plastic, stainless steel or glass. Aluminum and copper are not suitable for pickling.

steps.headline: Add the sugar, dill and vinegar to the vegetables.
Serve immediately.
steps.description: Quick pickled vegetables do not keep well.

steps.headline: Vary the recipe if you'd like with this Asian-style twist.
steps.description: Instead of the sugar, dill and vinegar in Step 8, add ½ tsp. sugar, ½ tsp. dark sesame oil, 1Tbs soy sauce and 1 tsp. rice vinegar.
